title: Frydenberg rejects states' asset recycling push
text:
Government reception

Mr Frydenberg, who is guarding his own plans to return the federal budget to surplus this year, was unreceptive.

"States have shown both a willingness and the ability to recycle their own assets and do not need a further cash incentive from the Commonwealth,'' he told The Australian Financial Review.

“States like NSW have a strong budget position from which they can leverage to fund their own infrastructure priorities."

Asset recycling was first introduced by then-treasurer Joe Hockey in 2014 and involved the Commonwealth paying 15 per cent of the cost of an infrastructure project from a $5 billion fund if the state was funding it from the proceeds of an asset privatisation.

NSW is looking at the sale or lease of its softwood plantation business and the possible sale of its remaining 49 per cent stake in the WestConnex road project.

Mr Perrottet argues asset recycling would leverage more Commonwealth funding towards large projects and free up state money for economy-boosting smaller projects.

Advertisement

But Mr Frydenberg said the Commonwealth was already doing enough in NSW, to which it has committed $32.9 billion in transport projects since 2013.

“A second airport for Sydney, WestConnex and upgrades to the Pacific Highway are among our important infrastructure commitments in that state,'' he said.

Infrastructure focus

Infrastructure will be a heavy focus of today's meeting, which aims to find ways to boost the economy by driving productivity.

In the short term, Mr Perrottet and his Victorian counterpart, Tim Pallas, agree that the best way the federal government can stimulate the economy is to bring forward funding for the maintenance and construction of small projects such as car parks and school projects.

Josh Frydenberg and Dominic Perrottet. AAP

The Treasurers agreed with Prime Minister Scott Morrison that capacity constraints caused by the current large infrastructure build mean no more large projects can be brought forward as a stimulus measure.

The federal government is holding out against spending more money, arguing its current policy settings are adequate. It is banking on the tax cuts which began on July 1 to start boosting growth.

Advertisement

The government will not know whether the tax cuts have worked until the September quarter National Accounts figures are released in early December.

Shadow treasurer Jim Chalmers said the states were right to push the Commonwealth to do more.

"If the Treasurer was doing his job the states wouldn’t be piling on the pressure to bring forward infrastructure investment,'' he said.

“Josh Frydenberg shouldn’t be using this as another opportunity to point the finger or pass the buck to distract from the economic failures of a third-term government.”

“The Morrison Government should bring forward the mid-year economic update (from December), and outline a plan to boost the economy and safeguard it from global turbulence.”

Mr Frydenberg has previously put pressure on business to help boost productivity by lifting investment.

At the same time, he is under pressure from Reserve bank Governor Philip Lowe to do more.

Mr Frydenberg pointed out that the states should be doing more outside of infrastructure.

"Lifting Australia's productivity will require the combined effort of the Commonwealth and state governments,'' he said.

"This is illustrated by the Productivity Commission's Shifting the Dial report which outlined 28 policy recommendations, 22 of which are either the sole or joint responsibilities of the states and territories.''
description: Josh Frydenberg has rejected a new push to bring back asset recycling as the state-federal infrastructure stand-off continues.
